newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australia hints at U.N. vote-buying.
newsitem.headline: Australia hints at U.N. vote-buying.

text.p: A stunned Australia said on Tuesday it was disappointed at failing to win a U.N. Security Council seat and hinted that vote-buying may have ruined its campaign.
Australia's ambassador to the United Nations Richard Butler said the outcome had stunned many in the U.N. and came after campaigning "marked by offers, threats and blandishments".
However, Butler said some U.N. members had unexpectedly paid their overdue U.N. fees in recent weeks, which enabled them to vote in the U.N. General Assembly ballots.
"Vote buying was not my term. That's what it has been called in a number of media reports," Butler said in a media briefing from New York. Butler cited a London Financial Times report.

"In recent days prior to this election, states that had not paid their dues to the U.N. suddenly came up with a cheque and paid them, which then made them eligible to vote," he said. "Now, I am not in a position to say how or why that happened, but that's been characterised in some media reports...as the possibility of something like vote-buying. Delinquent states' dues were paid in the understanding that they would vote in a certain way."
Butler said Australia lost more than 40 percent of its pledges in the final vote.
Costa Rica, Japan, Kenya, Portugal and Sweden were elected on Monday to the powerful 15-member U.N. Security Council for two-year terms beginning on January 1, 1997.
Sweden and Portugal battered Australia in a three-cornered race for two seats reserved for the group called West European and Others, now filled by Germany and Italy.

Australia, which has held a Security Council seat four times, lobbied for nearly two years for a seat and thought its effort in bringing the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty to the United Nations bolstered its candidature.
Australian Prime Minister John Howard said it was disappointing to not win a security council seat and has called on the country's foreign ministry to explain why the bid failed.
